Elections for the presidency of the Student Council will be
re-run next Wednesday and Thursday, SC President Bob
Peinado announced late yesterday evening. The original election was invalidatd, Peinado stated, by the 4-1 vote of members Of the committee which counted the ballots, because one
of the regulations set down by the Council was violated.
The violated regulation states that no ballots should be
counted before 2 p.m. Thursday, and was passed Monday by
the unanimous vote of the Council. The motion was effected
because it was felt by the Council that in last year's election,
knowledge of the first day's voting results may have influenced
the second day's voting. This year's violation took place, it
was explained to the committee (made up of Peinado, Sanford Cohen, Herbert Belgrad, Porter Claxton, and Howard
Waskow) when Peinado counted Wednesday night the results of Wednesday's balloting for the Student Council presidency, with Thursday's balloting yet to come.
The committee, acting for the Council through appointment -by Peinado, decided that the violation of the election
regulation necessitated the revote on the grounds that, although it was "highly probable'? that the election was not influenced by the premature vote-counting, the Council can

Dr. J. Hillis Miller, assistant
professor of English at the Hopkins, will deliver a lecture on the
poetry of Dylan Thomas, Wednesday at 11 a.m. in Gilman 111.
Emphasizing that he will not
give a reading, Dr. Miller said
the lecture will be an "attempt
to make a critical statement about
Thomas' poetry and to say what
it means."
The professor will attack the
subject from the idea of the "kind
of world we meet when we read
his poetry. I am interested in
what it means, and especially in
the way the poet is related to his
world," Dr. Miller stated.
"The lecture or some version
of it will be published in a book
of critical essays compiled by several people and which will come
out in a few years," Dr. Miller also
explained.
Dylan Thomas, a Welshman,
died in his early thirties in 1953.
Experts have named the major
themes in his poetry as birth,
copulation and death.

Weinstein noted that "nothing

but also to be a remembrance of

will continue to be as unified later
as they are now."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 13, 1956

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE TWO

Student Group Campaigns
For Stevenson's Nomination
Campus political activity at the
present time consists of plans for
a campaign by the Students for
Stevenson for the nomination of
the ex-governor of Illinois.
The Students for Democratic
Action will seek a speaker, while
the Young Republicans and the
Woodrow Wilson Club plan to remain inactive throughout the rest
of the year.
According to Reuben Lee, member of the Stevenson group, the
organization "will follow normal
campus political methods." It will
be "active in working in the Baltimore primaries for the election
of pro-Stevenson candidates" to
the National Democratic Convention, and will try to "get all qualified student voters out" to vote
in the primaries.
Precinct Work
It will also "set up organizations for precinct work" and will
distribute "handbills, buttons and
literature, although little work will
be done with posters," Lee said.
Lee also said he felt safe in
speaking for the group that
"Maryland's best chances for Stevenson's election would be with
Millard Tydings as the state's
Democratic nominee for the Senate. (Tydings, a veteran of the
Senate, was unseated by Republican John Marshall Butler in the
1950 Senatorial election, and is
now running again for his old
seat)"
Lee also noted that the Homewood campus had a "ratio of 3:1
or 4:1 in the last Presidential election year in favor of the Republicans" and that he •"expects the
story will be the same this year."
Seek 'Big Name'
Students for Democratic Action
failed to get Herb Block, Washington Post cartoonist, as a speaker,
and now are seeking another "big
name" politician through the parent organization, Americans for
Democratic Action. If a speaker is
found, The Bulletin, SDA's campus paper, will be published to advertise the speaker.

Papers written for academic
purposes will be accepted as entries in the Tudor and Stuart
Literary Contest, Richard Lidz,
executive secretary of the organization, announced recently.
In order to be considered, however, academic papers must first
be recommended by the instructor for whom they were written.
Eligibility, however, is not dependent upon the original purpose in
writing the paper. Essays prepared especially for the contest
may be submitted.
A prize of $40 will be awarded
to the best literary effort submitted, and an additional prize of
$40 will be given to the writer
of the best research essay dealing with some aspect of English
speaking civilization. A third prize
of $20 will be presented for the
best student library.
Judging of the libraries will be
primarily based upon a statement
of aims in building a library and
a list of representative books from
each collection entered.

Senior Awarded
Prize For Paper
Ted Smith, a senior in the
Chemical Engineering department,
won a second prize in a contest
at the Pennsylvania State University, April .7.
Smith, who at the Middle Atlantic Regional Conclave of the
American Institute of Chemical
Engineers was in competition with
representatives from seven other
schools in the region, won $25 for
his paper on "The Pressure Drop
Through a Packed Column."

GEORGE

Londoner To Offer
Frontier Lectures
Harry Cranbrook Allen, Commonwealth Fund Professor of
American History at the University of London, will deliver the
James Schouler Lectures in History and Political Science at Johns
Hopkins University next wek.
He will deliver four public lectures on "The Frontier in Australia and the United States." The
lectures will be held in the Goodwillie Room in Gilman Hall at
4:15 p.m., from Monday through
Thursday, and will be open to the
public.
Professor Allen, who holds the
only chair of American history in
the United Kingdom, is the author of "Great Britain and the
United States," a recently published comprehensive survey of
Anglo-American relations from
1776 to the present, with emphasis on recent history.
The James Schouler lectureship
in history and political science
was established in 1908.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 13, 1956

Faculty Club Improvement
Undertaken This Winter

Broadcasters Slate
Marathon Program
WJHU will present a marathon
broadcast for the World University Service Drive beginning on
noon April 14 and ending 24 hours
later, according to Station Manager Frank Zampiello.
The broadcast will begin in Levering Hall with interviews with
some of the WJHU board. Other
round-table interviews and music
will be included in this program.
In the early portion of the afternoon, the broadcast will move back
to the studio.
At the end of the lacrosse game
with Virginia, the program will
move to the snack bar, and then,
at 5 p.m., to the dining room where
the broadcast will continue until
6:30 p.m.
Concerning other station activities, Zampiello revealed that the
campus station hopes to join five
other stations in a network.

Peabody Players To Offer
Operas In Shriver In May
Three one-act operas will be
produced in Shriver Hall by the
Conservatory of Music of the Peabody Institute, May 4 and 5.
Dr. Brentano, director of the
Peabody Opera Company and director of the productions, was unavailable for comment, but Mr.
Charles Spatts, public relations director at Peabody, said that Dr.
Brentano felt that the rehearsals
are "progressing—they are going
ahead." Mr. Spatts also said that
the technical side of the production will be "on the simple side
—not too elaborate."

in Tahiti" by Leonard Bernstein,

Where would you want to work, Gay? The choice
isn't quite so wide as that reply indicates, but if you
have good reason for preferring a given area, and
Du Pont has an opening there for which you're
qualified, your choice will certainly be considered.
We have 69 plants and over 70 research and development laboratories scattered through 26 states.
So the odds are pretty fair that you can work in an
area you like.
Most of the Du Pont units are situated east of the
Mississippi, but some of them are as far west as the
Pacific Coast. Right now,new plants are under construction in Michigan and California, providing even
wider choice in those two states.
Of course, a man may be transferred after a time.
The chemical industry is a growth industry, and
transfers are generally associated with progress and
promotions.
So you see, Gay, the geography of the United
States is pretty much an open book for Du Pont
professional men, adding a lot to their interest and
enjoyment on the job.

Clayton B. Hill, Jr.. joined Du Pont's Jackson
Laboratory at Deepwater, N.J., in 1940 and left
for the Air Corps in 1942. After military service
he obtained a B.S.0h.E.from Pennsylvania State
University (1949), and returned to Jackson Laboratory. Clayton was assigned to Du Pont's
Atomic Energy Division fora period before transferring to the Personnel Division. As a representative of this Division, he currently visits many

Following a practice of twenty years, Pratt & Whitney
Aircraft will again welcome a group of college professors as members of the engineering staff during the
coming summer months.
Last year our "summer professors" represented colleges from coast to coast. They tackled important projects
in such diverse fields as-instrumentation. and vibration,
combustion, compressible flow, and materials development. Despite the limited time available to these men,
they made significant contributions to our overall effort.
Though it was to be expected that both the company and the participating professors might'benefit directly from such a program, the sphere of influence
has been much broader. The many students who are
taught by these professors during the college year are
sharing the ultimate benefits ... profiting from lectures
that are sparked by the kind of practical experience
that can be gained with a recognized industry leader
like Pratt & Whitney Aircraft.

"We are confronted with a situation in which the law of the
Council has been broken. We firmly believe that the election in all
probability has not been influenced
by the breaking of that law. We
Suspect that the second election
which we have ruled will take
place wilt be influenced to some
extent by the inescapable fact
that, despite the extreme caution
we have exercised, at least a general knowledge of the results of
the invalidated election has spread
over the campus. We fear that
this knowledge will tend to bias
the votes of voters in the second
election.
"However, we are forced to our
decision by the realization that
what we "believe" and what we
"suspect" and we "fear" cannot,
must not influence our ruling.
The Student Council and its committees cannot base its judgments
on assumptions. It must base its
judgments, instead, on the legislation it has passed. Although
it is entirely possible in this individual case that the intent behind the law—the avoidance of
voting results getting out to the
voting public before the final
ballots are cast— has remained
Unbroken, our only recourse is to
back up laws which were made
by the Council for the specific
purpose of insuring the sanctity
of the elections. Although our
ruling may result in a less fair
election than the first election,
we must stick to the principles
that we set up originally to govern the balloting. Assumptions
are dangerous. The super-structure of the law, which provides
for the continuing existence of the
Student Council, must be upheld,
although in a few isolated instances upholding it may yield
unfortunate results. If the superstructure is to be evaded and
skirted around, it is likely that it
will collapse.
Dissenting Vote
Peinado, who cast the dissenting

vote, explained his actions and
his voting position in the following manner:
"A law of the Council was
broken by my counting the votes
(with my roommate), ahead of
the prescribed time. Before counting the votes, I did consider the
ruling of the Council, but I felt
that I was not doing wrong because I knew that neither I nor
my roommate would spread the
results and by so doing influence
the election.
"I cast the dissenting vote in
the Committee after evaluating
two points: one, the legality of my
action; two, my feeling that the
first election would be more representative of the true, unbiased
opinions of the voters than any
other, following election possibly
could be. I felt strongly that the
importance of the second point
over-rode the technical illegality
of my actions.

Elections for the presidency of the Student Council will be
re-run next Wednesday and Thursday, SC President Bob
Peinado announced late yesterday evening. The original election was invalidatd, Peinado stated, by the 4-1 vote of members Of the committee which counted the ballots, because one
of the regulations set down by the Council was violated.
The violated regulation states that no ballots should be
counted before 2 p.m. Thursday, and was passed Monday by
the unanimous vote of the Council. The motion was effected
because it was felt by the Council that in last year's election,
knowledge of the first day's voting results may have influenced
the second day's voting. This year's violation took place, it
was explained to the committee (made up of Peinado, Sanford Cohen, Herbert Belgrad, Porter Claxton, and Howard
Waskow) when Peinado counted Wednesday night the results of Wednesday's balloting for the Student Council presidency, with Thursday's balloting yet to come.
The committee, acting for the Council through appointment -by Peinado, decided that the violation of the election
regulation necessitated the revote on the grounds that, although it was "highly probable'? that the election was not influenced by the premature vote-counting, the Council can

Dr. J. Hillis Miller, assistant
professor of English at the Hopkins, will deliver a lecture on the
poetry of Dylan Thomas, Wednesday at 11 a.m. in Gilman 111.
Emphasizing that he will not
give a reading, Dr. Miller said
the lecture will be an "attempt
to make a critical statement about
Thomas' poetry and to say what
it means."
The professor will attack the
subject from the idea of the "kind
of world we meet when we read
his poetry. I am interested in
what it means, and especially in
the way the poet is related to his
world," Dr. Miller stated.
"The lecture or some version
of it will be published in a book
of critical essays compiled by several people and which will come
out in a few years," Dr. Miller also
explained.
Dylan Thomas, a Welshman,
died in his early thirties in 1953.
Experts have named the major
themes in his poetry as birth,
copulation and death.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 13, 1956

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE TWO

Student Group Campaigns
For Stevenson's Nomination
Campus political activity at the
present time consists of plans for
a campaign by the Students for
Stevenson for the nomination of
the ex-governor of Illinois.
The Students for Democratic
Action will seek a speaker, while
the Young Republicans and the
Woodrow Wilson Club plan to remain inactive throughout the rest
of the year.
According to Reuben Lee, member of the Stevenson group, the
organization "will follow normal
campus political methods." It will
be "active in working in the Baltimore primaries for the election
of pro-Stevenson candidates" to
the National Democratic Convention, and will try to "get all qualified student voters out" to vote
in the primaries.
Precinct Work
It will also "set up organizations for precinct work" and will
distribute "handbills, buttons and
literature, although little work will
be done with posters," Lee said.
Lee also said he felt safe in
speaking for the group that
"Maryland's best chances for Stevenson's election would be with
Millard Tydings as the state's
Democratic nominee for the Senate. (Tydings, a veteran of the
Senate, was unseated by Republican John Marshall Butler in the
1950 Senatorial election, and is
now running again for his old
seat)"
Lee also noted that the Homewood campus had a "ratio of 3:1
or 4:1 in the last Presidential election year in favor of the Republicans" and that he •"expects the
story will be the same this year."
Seek 'Big Name'
Students for Democratic Action
failed to get Herb Block, Washington Post cartoonist, as a speaker,
and now are seeking another "big
name" politician through the parent organization, Americans for
Democratic Action. If a speaker is
found, The Bulletin, SDA's campus paper, will be published to advertise the speaker.

Papers written for academic
purposes will be accepted as entries in the Tudor and Stuart
Literary Contest, Richard Lidz,

In order to be considered, however, academic papers must first
be recommended by the instructor for whom they were written.
Eligibility, however, is not dependent upon the original purpose in
writing the paper. Essays prepared especially for the contest
may be submitted.
A prize of $40 will be awarded
to the best literary effort submitted, and an additional prize of
$40 will be given to the writer
of the best research essay dealing with some aspect of English
speaking civilization. A third prize
of $20 will be presented for the
best student library.
Judging of the libraries will be
primarily based upon a statement
of aims in building a library and
a list of representative books from
each collection entered.

a presentation by the winner of
the Inter-Fraternity Sing.

Londoner To Offer
Frontier Lectures
Harry Cranbrook Allen, Commonwealth Fund Professor of
American History at the University of London, will deliver the
James Schouler Lectures in History and Political Science at Johns
Hopkins University next wek.
He will deliver four public lectures on "The Frontier in Australia and the United States." The
lectures will be held in the Goodwillie Room in Gilman Hall at
4:15 p.m., from Monday through
Thursday, and will be open to the
public.
Professor Allen, who holds the
only chair of American history in
the United Kingdom, is the author of "Great Britain and the
United States," a recently published comprehensive survey of
Anglo-American relations from
1776 to the present, with emphasis on recent history.
The James Schouler lectureship
in history and political science
was established in 1908.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 13, 1956

Faculty Club Improvement
Undertaken This Winter

Broadcasters Slate
Marathon Program
WJHU will present a marathon
broadcast for the World University Service Drive beginning on
noon April 14 and ending 24 hours
later, according to Station Manager Frank Zampiello.
The broadcast will begin in Levering Hall with interviews with
some of the WJHU board. Other
round-table interviews and music
will be included in this program.
In the early portion of the afternoon, the broadcast will move back
to the studio.
At the end of the lacrosse game
with Virginia, the program will
move to the snack bar, and then,
at 5 p.m., to the dining room where
the broadcast will continue until
6:30 p.m.
Concerning other station activities, Zampiello revealed that the
campus station hopes to join five
other stations in a network.

Operas In Shriver In May
Three one-act operas will be
produced in Shriver Hall by the
Conservatory of Music of the Peabody Institute, May 4 and 5.

Peabody Opera Company and director of the productions, was unavailable for comment, but Mr.
Charles Spatts, public relations director at Peabody, said that Dr.
Brentano felt that the rehearsals
are "progressing—they are going
ahead." Mr. Spatts also said that
the technical side of the production will be "on the simple side
—not too elaborate."

in Tahiti" by Leonard Bernstein,

Where would you want to work, Gay? The choice
isn't quite so wide as that reply indicates, but if you
have good reason for preferring a given area, and
Du Pont has an opening there for which you're
qualified, your choice will certainly be considered.
We have 69 plants and over 70 research and development laboratories scattered through 26 states.
So the odds are pretty fair that you can work in an
area you like.
Most of the Du Pont units are situated east of the
Mississippi, but some of them are as far west as the
Pacific Coast. Right now,new plants are under construction in Michigan and California, providing even
wider choice in those two states.
Of course, a man may be transferred after a time.
The chemical industry is a growth industry, and
transfers are generally associated with progress and
promotions.
So you see, Gay, the geography of the United
States is pretty much an open book for Du Pont
professional men, adding a lot to their interest and
enjoyment on the job.

"We are confronted with a situation in which the law of the
Council has been broken. We firmly believe that the election in all
probability has not been influenced
by the breaking of that law. We
Suspect that the second election
which we have ruled will take
place wilt be influenced to some
extent by the inescapable fact
that, despite the extreme caution
we have exercised, at least a general knowledge of the results of
the invalidated election has spread
over the campus. We fear that
this knowledge will tend to bias
the votes of voters in the second
election.
"However, we are forced to our
decision by the realization that
what we "believe" and what we
"suspect" and we "fear" cannot,
must not influence our ruling.
The Student Council and its committees cannot base its judgments
on assumptions. It must base its
judgments, instead, on the legislation it has passed. Although
it is entirely possible in this individual case that the intent behind the law—the avoidance of
voting results getting out to the
voting public before the final
ballots are cast— has remained
Unbroken, our only recourse is to
back up laws which were made
by the Council for the specific
purpose of insuring the sanctity
of the elections. Although our
ruling may result in a less fair
election than the first election,
we must stick to the principles
that we set up originally to govern the balloting. Assumptions
are dangerous. The super-structure of the law, which provides
for the continuing existence of the
Student Council, must be upheld,
although in a few isolated instances upholding it may yield
unfortunate results. If the superstructure is to be evaded and
skirted around, it is likely that it
will collapse.
Dissenting Vote
Peinado, who cast the dissenting

vote, explained his actions and
his voting position in the following manner:
"A law of the Council was
broken by my counting the votes
(with my roommate), ahead of
the prescribed time. Before counting the votes, I did consider the
ruling of the Council, but I felt
that I was not doing wrong because I knew that neither I nor
my roommate would spread the
results and by so doing influence
the election.
"I cast the dissenting vote in
the Committee after evaluating
two points: one, the legality of my
action; two, my feeling that the
first election would be more representative of the true, unbiased
opinions of the voters than any
other, following election possibly
could be. I felt strongly that the
importance of the second point
over-rode the technical illegality
of my actions.
